content:
Consider a profunctor P:B⇸AP : B ⇸ AP:B⇸A equipped with the following data:

  • for each a∈Aa \in Aa∈A, an object bab_{a}ba​ of BBB and an element pap_{a}pa​ of P(a,ba)P(a,b_{a})P(a,ba​)
  • such that each element ppp of any P(a,b)P(a,b)P(a,b) appears as P(f,id)pa′P(f,id) p_{a'}P(f,id)pa′​ for some unique a′a'a′, fff.

From this data we can reconstruct a cofunctor φ:A↛B\varphi : A \nrightarrow Bφ:A↛B as follows:

  • φ0(a)=ba\varphi_{0}(a) = b_{a}φ0​(a)=ba​
  • φ1(f)\varphi_{1}(f)φ1​(f) for f:φ0(a)→bf : \varphi_{0}(a) \to bf:φ0​(a)→b is the unique ggg such that P(id,f)pa=P(g,id)pa′P(id,f) p_{a} = P(g,id) p_{a'}P(id,f)pa​=P(g,id)pa′​.

Is there a nicer way to characterize the above data, and/or to reconstruct any of it given some property of PPP?

Oh, and you go the other way as follows:

  • P(a,b)=∐φ0(a′)=bA(a,a′)P(a,b) = \coprod_{\varphi_{0}(a')=b} A(a,a')P(a,b)=∐φ0​(a′)=b​A(a,a′)
  • ba=φ0(a)b_{a} = \varphi_{0}(a)ba​=φ0​(a)
  • $p_{a} = \varphi_{1}(id_{a})$
  • pa=φ1(idφ0(a))=idap_a = \varphi_1(id_{\varphi_{0}(a)}) = id_{a}pa​=φ1​(idφ0​(a)​)=ida​.
This is interesting! I'll have a think about it and post something later today / this week. Ping me if I forget!

James Deikun said:

  • such that each element ppp of any P(a,b)P(a,b)P(a,b) appears as P(f,id)pa′P(f,id) p_{a'}P(f,id)pa′​ for some unique a′a'a′, fff.

So I'm a bit confused as to what this bit is trying to say. Could you provide some intuition as to what you mean?
fff is a morphism from what to what? Below it looks like it is a morphism in BBB, whereas here it appears to be a morphism of AAA?
You're correct that below it is a morphism in BBB. Here, though, it is f:a→a′f : a \to a'f:a→a′; basically (a′,f)(a',f)(a′,f) is a unique dependent pair.

The way I came up with it is thinking of the collage of PPP where this is a factorization of sorts (not orthogonal) of morphisms that go from the AAA-part to the BBB-part. As seen below in the "other way" part, the pap_{a}pa​ are the lifts of identity morphisms through each aaa, viewed as "heteromorphisms" from aaa to φ0(a)\varphi_{0}(a)φ0​(a). Because they are lifts of identity morphisms, they are also identity morphisms in aaa. In fact I need to update that part because I messed it up; please check it again.

Anyway the way lifts work is you compose with an "identity" on one side to turn the morphism in B into a heteromorphism (this part does most of the actual work) and then factor through an "identity" on the other side to turn it into a morphism in A.

As for how PPP itself is put together from φ\varphiφ, this is what it looks like when you compose A(1,F)∘Λ(G,1)A(1,F) \circ \Lambda(G,1)A(1,F)∘Λ(G,1) for FFF a bijective-on-objects functor and GGG a discrete opfibration such that the span represents φ\varphiφ.
Don't have enough time to look closely enough, but, just in case, this makes me think of [[two-sided discrete fibrations]]. You know about them, I guess?
I do know about them and their relevance to profunctors in general, but I'm not sure where you're specifically seeing them here.
I was not, really. It was just a quick, vague intuition. Sorry if that was unclear, and even more sorry if it was bad intuition!

For comparison I decided to try to describe representable profunctors in a similar way:

A representable profunctor is a profunctor P:A⇸BP : A ⇸ BP:A⇸B equipped with the following data:

  • for each a∈Aa \in Aa∈A, an object bab_aba​ of BBB and an element pap_apa​ of P(ba,a)P(b_a,a)P(ba​,a)
  • such that each element ppp of any P(b,a)P(b,a)P(b,a) appears as P(f,id) paP(f,id)\,p_{a}P(f,id)pa​ for some unique f:b→baf : b \to b_af:b→ba​.

From this data we can reconstruct a functor F:A→BF : A \to BF:A→B as follows:

  • F0(a)=baF_0(a) = b_aF0​(a)=ba​
  • F1(f)F_1(f)F1​(f) for f:a→a′f : a \to a'f:a→a′ is the unique ggg such that P(id,f) pa=P(g,id) pa′P(id,f)\,p_a = P(g,id)\,p_{a'}P(id,f)pa​=P(g,id)pa′​.

Other way:

  • P(b,a)=B(b,F0(a))P(b,a) = B(b,F_0(a))P(b,a)=B(b,F0​(a))
  • ba=F0(a)b_a = F_0(a)ba​=F0​(a)
  • pa=F1(ida)=idF0(a)p_a = F_1(id_a) = id_{F_0(a)}pa​=F1​(ida​)=idF0​(a)​.
